name: This Too Shall Pass
summary: Ancient wisdom reminding us of the impermanence of all states, both good and bad.
explanation: This too shall pass is an ancient adage appearing in Persian, Jewish, and other wisdom traditions, reminding us that all states are temporary - both suffering and joy. The wisdom serves dual purposes: during difficulty, it provides comfort (pain will end); during pleasure, it counsels humility (good times won't last forever). The phrase embodies: recognition of impermanence as fundamental reality, perspective that current states are not permanent, and equanimity arising from this understanding. The teaching helps: in suffering (providing hope), in success (preventing arrogance), in attachment (reminding of transience), and in anxiety (contextualizing current concerns). The wisdom differs from: pessimism (it applies equally to good and bad), dismissiveness (current states still matter), and passivity (action is still appropriate). Understanding impermanence actually increases appreciation - knowing something will end makes it more precious. For knowledge workers, this wisdom helps: maintain perspective during setbacks, stay humble during successes, and maintain equanimity across the inevitable fluctuations of work and career.
